sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using QR decomposition
message_1:
Solve the system of linear equations given below using QR Decomposition:

3x + 4y + 5z = 23
2x - 3y + 4z = 2
x + 2y - 3z = -7

(Round the solutions to the nearest hundredth)
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using QR decomposition, we first need to represent the system in matrix form Ax = b, where A is the matrix of coefficients, x is the column vector of variables, and b is the column vector of constants.

A = | 3  4  5 |
    | 2 -3  4 |
    | 1  2 -3 |

b = | 23 |
    |  2 |
    | -7 |

Now, we need to perform QR decomposition on matrix A, which means we need to find orthogonal matrix Q and upper triangular matrix R such that A = QR.

Using the Gram-Schmidt process, we can find the orthogonal matrix Q and upper triangular matrix R.

First, we find the orthogonal basis for the column space of A:

u1 = a1 = | 3 |
          | 2 |
          | 1 |

u2 = a2 - proj(u1, a2) = |  4  |
                          | -3  |
                          |  2  |

u3 = a3 - proj(u1, a3) - proj(u2, a3) = |  5  |
                                        |  4  |
                                        | -3  |

Next, we normalize the orthogonal basis vectors to get the orthonormal basis:

q1 = u1 / ||u1|| = | 3/√14 |
                  | 2/√14 |
                  | 1/√14 |

q2 = u2 / ||u2|| = |  4/√29 |
                  | -3/√29 |
                  |  2/√29 |

q3 = u3 / ||u3|| = |  5/√50 |
                  |  4/√50 |
                  | -3/√50 |

Now, we have the orthogonal matrix Q:

Q = | 3/√14  4/√29  5/√50 |
    | 2/√14 -3/√29  4/√50 |
    | 1/√14  2/√29 -3/√50 |

To find the upper triangular matrix R, we can use the following equations:

R = | r11 r12 r13 |
    |  0  r22 r23 |
    |  0   0  r33 |

r11 = <q1, a1> = √14
r12 = <q1, a2> = 2√14
r22 = <q2, a2> = √29
r13 = <q1, a3> = 3√14
r23 = <q2, a3> = 2√29
r33 = <q3, a3> = √50

R = | √14  2√14  3√14 |
    |  0    √29  2√29 |
    |  0     0    √50 |

Now, we have A = QR. To solve the system Ax = b, we can use the following steps:

1. Solve Q^T * b = c
2. Solve Rx = c

Q^T = | 3/√14  2/√14  1/√14 |
      | 4/√29 -3/√29  2/√29 |
      | 5/√50  4/√50 -3/√50 |

Q^T * b = | (3/√14)(23) + (2/√14)(2) + (1/√14)(-7) |
          | (4/√29)(23) - (3/√29)(2) + (2/√29)(-7) |
          | (5/√50)(23) + (4/√50)(2) - (3/√50)(-7) |

Q^T * b = | 14 |
          | 29 |
          | 50 |

Now, we can solve Rx = c using back-substitution:

| √14  2√14  3√14 | | x |   | 14 |
|  0    √29  2√29 | | y | = | 29 |
|  0     0    √50 | | z |   | 50 |

z = 50 / √50 ≈ 7.07
y = (29 - 2√29 * 7.07) / √29 ≈ -3.03
x = (14 - 2√14 * (-3.03) - 3√14 * 7.07) / √14 ≈ 1.00

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is approximately:

x ≈ 1.00
y ≈ -3.03
z ≈ 7.07
